item.title: How To Watch the 2025–2026 NBA G League Season
item.dc:creator: Eric Chiu
item.description:
Want to track your NBA team’s most interesting prospects? Here’s how to watch NBA G League games this year.

The post How To Watch the 2025–2026 NBA G League Season appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
From Scoot Henderson to Khris Middleton, the NBA G League has long been a proving ground for hidden gems and future superstars. It’s often the first home for many developmental prospects, laying the foundation for tomorrow’s NBA talent. The 2025–2026 season, which tips off in November, promises to showcase this rising talent as it runs through April.

Whether you’re tracking that promising draft pick your team sent down or following the high-energy local atmosphere, here’s what you need to know about watching the NBA G League this season.

Score the best internet for streaming basketball

Get the fastest NBA streams with a high-end internet connection. Enter your zip code below to see the best internet providers in your area.

1. Get a live TV service

You can watch the 2025–2026 NBA G League regular season on the following channels and platforms:

  • NBAGLeague.com
  • ESPN+
  • NBA TV
  • The Roku Channel
  • Tubi

If you’re interested in NBA G League games, we’d wager that you’re also interested in regular NBA games. In this case, we’d recommend getting DIRECTV STREAM. Along with features like full cable channel lineups and regional sports network coverage, DIRECTV STREAM also includes NBA TV, which will be the home of many NBA G League games.

GET DIRECTV STREAM

2. Sign up for NBA League Pass

Are you stuck on a cable TV plan that doesn’t include NBA TV? NBA League Pass is the easiest a la carte way to add NBA TV to your NBA rotation. The streaming service costs $16.99–$24.99/mo. and includes NBA TV along with full out-of-market game coverage for the entire NBA season. Plus, you can view League Pass on platforms including PlayStation consoles, Apple TVs, and Google TVs.

Check out our NBA League Pass review to learn more about the NBA’s streaming service.

Get NBA League Pass

Want more TV sports coverage?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest must-watch sporting events, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

3. Get ESPN+

Along with NBA G League games, ESPN’s streaming service includes exclusive coverage from top ESPN writers like David Shoenfield, live sports games, and original shows. The service typically costs $11.99/mo., but you can get it for free as part of the Disney Bundle, which includes Disney+, Hulu, and ESPN+.

Check out our full ESPN+ review to learn more about the ESPN streaming service.

Get ESPN+

4. Brush up on the NBA G League schedule

If it’s your first time following NBA G League games, remember that its schedule is formatted differently than the NBA. Here are some of the big dates for the 2024–2025 NBA G League season:

Event Start date
NBA G League International Draft July 8, 2025
NBA G League Draft Oct. 25, 2025
NBA G League Tip-Off Tournament Nov. 7, 2025
NBA G League regular season Dec. 19, 2025
NBA G League Playoffs March 31, 2026

Data effective as of post date.

How to watch NBA G League FAQ

Where can I watch NBA G League games?

NBA G League games typically air on ESPN+, NBA TV, Tubi, The Roku Channel, and the NBA G League website. ESPN+ requires a subscription, but NBA TV is available on many cable TV plans and via NBA League Pass.

When does the NBA G League start?

The 2025–2026 NBA G League action begins November 7, with the Tip-Off Tournament. Then, the 36-game regular season begins on December 19.

Are NBA G League games televised?

Yes, most NBA G Leagues are televised on regional sports networks or over-the-air stations within each team's TV market. NBA TV, ESPN+, The Roku Channel, and Tubi also broadcast occasional games nationwide.

How can I watch the NBA G League Playoffs?

The 2026 NBA G League Playoffs will air across ESPNews, ESPNU, and Tubi. Select games may also appear on regional sports platforms, like the FanDuel Sports Network app.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com senior writer, Eric Chiu, researched and tested various ways to watch the NBA G League on TV. He analyzed this season’s schedule and channel listings. Then, he evaluated viewing options across multiple services, determining his top choices based on game quantity, pricing, and ease of use.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Game day starts here!

item.title: 650 Hours of Horror: How to Watch AMC’s FearFest 2025
item.dc:creator: Randy Harward
item.description:
The 31 Nights of Halloween are back! From October 1–31, you’ll be able to enjoy your favorite spooky classics every day on the Freeform channel.

The post 650 Hours of Horror: How to Watch AMC’s FearFest 2025 appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Watch Free on Fubo

What is AMC’s FearFest 2025?

AMC’s FearFest is an annual event where AMC and AMC+ air 650 hours of horror movies, TV series, specials, and more throughout October. Like last year, AMC FearFest 2025 will be hosted by artist/musician/horror aficionado Janelle Monáe, who AMC is calling FearFest’s “HalloQueen.”

In addition to hosting, Monáe has also curated a list of her favorite freaky films, including The Birds, Carrie (1976), Child’s Play (1988), the OG Halloween (1978), Jeepers Creepers, Late Night with the Devil, Leprechaun, The Others, Psycho (1960), and more.

Other FearFest programming includes franchise marathons (A Nightmare on Elm Street, Final Destination, Friday the 13th, and Halloween) and curated days dedicated to ’80s horror, creature features, and Stephen King.

I’ve included the complete schedule—all 175 lines of it—below. Happy FearFest!

Complete AMC FearFest schedule (2025)

Okay, FearFest fans, here’s everything AMC and AMC+ plans to screen over 31 days of Halloween. Note that you’ll have multiple opportunities to catch some of the marathons in case you have to work or some such drudgery.

item.title: How To Watch The Conjuring Universe Movies in Order
item.dc:creator: Taylor Kujawa
item.description:
The Conjuring debuted in 2013 to much box office and critical success. Under director James Wan, the film set the stage for a new horror movie franchise that continues to fright audiences worldwide.

The post How To Watch The Conjuring Universe Movies in Order appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
The Conjuring debuted in 2013 to much box office and critical success. Under director James Wan, renowned for his earlier hits with Saw and Insidious, The Conjuring set the stage for a new horror movie franchise that continues to frighten audiences worldwide.

As we delve deeper into the realm of paranormal investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren, one question inevitably arises: In what order should you watch The Conjuring movies?

In this article, I’ll guide you through the daunting maze of sequels, prequels, and spin-offs—ensuring you’re ready to navigate a universe where demonic possession runs rampant. Join me as I unravel the chilling tapestry of The Conjuring franchise and help you unlock the perfect sequence for your next spine-tingling movie marathon.

Jump to:

  • What is The Conjuring universe?
  • The Conjuring universe release order
  • The Conjuring universe chronological order
  • Rent or buy The Conjuring universe movies

Sponsored by DIRECTV

Binge-watch more of your favorite shows with DIRECTV

When the leaves fall, Fall TV shows drop—streaming with DIRECTV can make sure you catch them. New subscribers get three months of HBO Max™, Paramount+ with SHOWTIME, STARZ®, Cinemax®, and MGM+™ included with select packages (a $175 value).

You can watch a lot in three months, trust us, as professional TV watchers, the CableTV.com staff knows. Catch up on summer hits like The White Lotus and Dexter: Resurrection, and get into the new season of Peacemaker, or new shows like Outlander: Blood of My Blood and It: Welcome to Derry.

Sign up for a free trial today to see how DIRECTV is revolutionizing streaming TV with its Signature Packages, innovative Gemini streaming device, and curated Genre Packs. This is DIRECTV like you’ve never seen it.

Is your Wi-Fi as haunted as the Warren’s house?

If buffering during movie night is your real horror story, it might be time for an internet upgrade. Enter your zip code below to check out the best internet providers in your area.

What is The Conjuring universe?

The Conjuring universe is a cinematic franchise created by filmmaker James Wan. At its core, the series revolves around the paranormal investigations of real-life couple Ed and Lorraine Warren (portrayed by Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga).

The world-renowned Warrens don’t appear in every Conjuring universe film, but each installment interconnects and expands on the Warrens’ encounters. That’s where malevolent entities like Annabelle and Valak the Nun come into play.

List of The Conjuring universe movies

  • The Conjuring (2013)
  • Annabelle (2014)
  • The Conjuring 2 (2016)
  • Annabelle: Creation (2017)
  • The Nun (2018)
  • The Curse of La Llorona (2019)
  • Annabelle Comes Home (2019)
  • The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It (2021)
  • The Nun II (2023)
  • The Conjuring: Last Rites (2025)

I include The Curse of La Llorona on the list of The Conjuring movies because it connects to the first Annabelle film. But director Michael Chaves told Dread Central the film doesn’t belong in the franchise due to its lack of involvement from The Conjuring producer Peter Safran.

Beyond The Conjuring universe, the Annabelle doll has cheeky appearances in the DC Extended Universe movies Aquaman (2018), Shazam! (2019), and Shazam! Fury of the Gods (2023).

Looking for the hottest entertainment?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest TV event viewing guides, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

Watch The Conjuring universe in release order

In this section, I’ll guide you through watching The Conjuring movies in order based on release date. Thanks to JustWatch, I’ve included links to streaming services and video-on-demand (VOD) retailers that offer each film online.

Where to watch The Conjuring (2013)

Watch Options

Where to watch Annabelle (2014)

Watch Options

Where to watch The Conjuring 2 (2016)

Watch Options

Where to watch Annabelle: Creation (2017)

Watch Options

Where to watch The Nun (2018)

Watch Options

Where to watch The Curse of La Llorona (2019)

Watch Options

Where to watch Annabelle Comes Home (2019)

Watch Options

Where to watch The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It (2021)

Watch Options

Where to watch The Nun II (2023)

Watch Options

Where to watch The Conjuring: Last Rites (2025)

The Conjuring: Last Rites hit theaters on September 5. Its now available to rent or buy at video-on-demand (VOD) outlets, but it’s not on a subscription-based streaming service yet. When that happens, it will likely be available on HBO Max.

Watch Options

Watch The Conjuring universe in chronological order

Watching The Conjuring movies in chronological order is less jarring than in release order. However, there are several inconsistencies throughout the franchise timeline. As Annabelle: Creation director David F. Sandberg humorously wrote on Reddit, “Let’s just say that if god can work in mysterious ways, then the devil probably does too.”

Below, you’ll find the complete Conjuring chronological timeline. Although some installments feature time jumps, I arranged each movie according to the year it primarily takes place.

  • 1952 – The Nun
  • 1956 – The Nun II
  • 1958 – Annabelle: Creation
  • 1970 – Annabelle
  • 1971 – The Conjuring
  • 1972 – Annabelle Comes Home
  • 1973 – The Curse of Llorona
  • 1977 – The Conjuring 2
  • 1981 – The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It
  • 1986 – The Conjuring: Last Rites

Rent or buy The Conjuring universe movies

You can unlock the eerie tales of The Conjuring universe with multiple on-demand viewing options. As the JustWatch links above highlight, each film is available for digital rental or purchase on platforms like Amazon Prime Video, Apple TV, and Fandango at Home (formerly Vudu). Cable and satellite TV subscribers may also find some installments available through their provider’s on-demand service.

For collectors like myself, physical copies of The Conjuring movies are available on DVD, Blu-ray, and 4K UHD Blu-ray. Online retailers like Amazon and Walmart carry multiple formats of each film.

Pro tip: Nothing’s scarier than missing your favorite movies due to device limitations. Visit our Best Smart TVs guide to browse our favorite TVs on the market.

How to watch The Conjuring universe FAQ

Does HBO Max have The Conjuring universe?

Yes, The Conjuring universe movies are typically available to stream on HBO Max. But occasionally, even Warner Bros. Pictures titles leave HBO Max due to existing licensing agreements and content shuffling.

How is La Llorona connected to The Conjuring?

The Curse of La Llorona connects to The Conjuring universe by using actor Tony Amendola as Father Perez, who previously appeared in Annabelle. The film even features a flashback of Father Perez during his not-so-joyous time with the vintage porcelain doll.

What will be the next Conjuring movie?

After The Nun II, the next film in The Conjuring universe will be The Conjuring: Last Rites. Warner Bros. announced the film’s title at CinemaCon 2023, but the actors’ and writers’ strikes delayed its production. It’s now set to hit theaters on September 5, 2025.

item.title: He Came Home: How to Watch the Halloween Movies in Order
item.dc:creator: Randy Harward
item.description:
Do you love the Halloween movies and their masked mascot Michael Myers? So do we. And, since binge-watching works for movies, we wanna watch all of the Halloween films in order. If you like the idea, here's where to stream, rent, or buy all 13 films in the series.

The post He Came Home: How to Watch the Halloween Movies in Order appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
In what order should I watch the Halloween movies?

Do you love the Halloween movies and their masked mascot Michael Myers? So do we. Not just John Carpenter’s original 1978 film and 1981 sequel, but all of them—even you, Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers. With Michael’s special day comin’ up, we wanna watch the the Halloween films in order. If you like the idea, here’s where to stream, rent, or buy all 13 films in the series.

Sponsored by DIRECTV

Binge-watch more of your favorite shows with DIRECTV

When the leaves fall, Fall TV shows drop—streaming with DIRECTV can make sure you catch them. New subscribers get three months of HBO Max™, Paramount+ with SHOWTIME, STARZ®, Cinemax®, and MGM+™ included with select packages (a $175 value).

You can watch a lot in three months, trust us, as professional TV watchers, the CableTV.com staff knows. Catch up on summer hits like The White Lotus and Dexter: Resurrection, and get into the new season of Peacemaker, or new shows like Outlander: Blood of My Blood and It: Welcome to Derry.

Sign up for a free trial today to see how DIRECTV is revolutionizing streaming TV with its Signature Packages, innovative Gemini streaming device, and curated Genre Packs. This is DIRECTV like you’ve never seen it.

Buffering kills the suspense

Does your internet move slowly, like Michael Myers? Enter your zip code to find fastest internet service near you.

Jump to:

  • List of Halloween movies
  • Watch the Halloween movies in order
  • Rent or buy the Halloween movies

Pro tip: Watching every Halloween movie in order will take 21 hours and 7 minutes.

What are the Halloween movies?

After, at age 6, murdering his sister and her boyfriend on Halloween 1963, Michael Myers busted outta Smith’s Grove Sanitarium on Halloween 1978 to continue his slow-mo stalking, slicing, and stabbing ways. Quality and lore fluctuate throughout the series, but after 46 years and 13 films, Michael is a horror icon worthy of immortalization on Mount Slashmore (if there were such a monument).

Michael Myers on the night he left home—before returning exactly 15 years later. (Video screenshot from YouTube)

How to watch the Halloween movies in order

No streaming service has all 13 Halloween films. So if you want to stage a mega-marathon, you’ll need to use multiple streaming TV services and some video-on-demand (VOD) rentals. Use the lists below to see how to watch the Halloween movies in release or chronological order. Click on a movie to see JustWatch.com data on where to stream, rent, or buy it.

Halloween movies in release order

  • Halloween (1978)
  • Halloween II (1981)
  • Halloween III: Season of the Witch (1982)
  • Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers (1988)
  • Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers (1989)
  • Halloween: The Curse of Michael Myers (1995)
  • Halloween H20: Twenty Years Later (1998)
  • Halloween: Resurrection (2002)
  • Rob Zombie’s Halloween (2007)
  • Rob Zombie’s Halloween II (2009)
  • Halloween (2018)
  • Halloween Kills (2021)
  • Halloween Ends (2022)

Halloween movies in chronological order

Watching the Halloween movies in chronological order is complicated thanks to there being 13 films—one of which, Halloween III: Season of the Witch, doesn’t fit the series—plus reboots/remakes/re-quels, and retconning that further muck up the timeline. That doesn’t have to be such a bad thing, though.

We’ve broken it down into four timelines below, plus this recommendation: Don’t skip Halloween III even though it skipped Michael Myers. If you leave your expectations on the sanitarium floor before pressing “play,” you’ll probably still dig it.

Halloween movies: The main timeline

  1. Halloween (1978)
  2. Halloween II (1981)
  3. Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers (1988)
  4. Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers (1989)
  5. Halloween: The Curse of Michael Myers (1995)

Halloween movies: The H20 timeline

  1. Halloween (1978)
  2. Halloween II (1981)
  3. Halloween H20: Twenty Years Later (1998)
  4. Halloween: Resurrection (2002)

Halloween movies: The Zombie timeline

  1. Halloween (1978)
  2. Rob Zombie’s Halloween (2007)
  3. Rob Zombie’s Halloween II (2009)

Halloween movies: The H40 timeline

  • Halloween (1978)
  • Halloween (2018)
  • Halloween Kills (2021)
  • Halloween Ends (2022)

Where to watch Halloween (1978)

John Carpenter’s original Halloween helped spark the slasher movie boom of 1978–1984 and remains freaky today. And let’s give it up for Jamie Lee Curtis, forever our favorite scream queen, as Michael Myers’ mystery fixation Laurie Strode.

Watch Options

Pro tip: Try watching Halloween (1978) with a pro. Esteemed author, horror host, and raconteur Joe Bob Briggs adds hilarious, insightful commentary to Michael Myers’ debut in Joe Bob’s Halloween Hootenanny on Shudder.

Where to watch Halloween II (1981)

A continuation of The Night He Came Home, Halloween II is where we discover a reason for Michael’s pursuit of Laurie. No spoilers, though.

Watch Options

Where to watch Halloween III: Season of the Witch (1982)

John Carpenter wanted to get away from telling Michael Myers stories and make Halloween an anthology series with other directors at the helm. So instead of more stalk-n’-chop action, we got a sci-fi flavored horror story (directed by Tommy Lee Wallace) about three Halloween masks that kill you and shoot creepy crawlies at everyone else.

Watch Options

Pro tip: You can probably skip Halloween III: Season of the Witch when you watch the Halloween movies in order. Michael Myers isn’t in it, and it’s completely unrelated to the other films. Watch it later, though, since Halloween III is good enough to have a cult following.

Where to watch Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers (1988)

Michael Myers, back by popular demand after his disappointing exclusion from the franchise’s third film, chops it up with a new pint-sized scream queen, Jamie Lloyd (Danielle Harris), if the first film of what Halloween fans call The Thorn Trilogy.

Watch Options

Check out the best horror streaming services

If you want to watch horror movies all day, every day, check out Shudder, Screambox, Full Moon Features, Arrow Player, and Night Flight Plus. (Or, for one-stop shopping, consult our guide to the Best Streaming Services for Horror Fans.)

Where to watch Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers (1989)

Michael’s out for revenge against Jamie Lloyd, but instead of a scorched-earth rampage, the big, bad slasher sheds a tear while boring us to tears. Also, what was up with the pennywhistle sound effect?

Watch Options

Where to watch Halloween: The Curse of Michael Myers (1995)

What’s scarier than a psycho-killer with four movies worth of body count behind him? The same guy in league with Satanic druids. Features Paul Rudd as Tommy Doyle in his very first film role. The last film in The Thorn Trilogy.

Watch Options

More horror franchise guides

  • How to Watch the I Know What You Did Last Summer Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Texas Chainsaw Massacre Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Terrifier Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Alien Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Friday the 13th Movies in Order

Where to watch Halloween H20: Twenty Years Later (1998)

The Halloween series comes to its senses and returns to the canon, bringing back Jamie Lee Curtis as Laurie Strode—and returns the story to the original thread that started with Halloween and Halloween II.

Watch Options

Where to watch Halloween: Resurrection (2002)

Laurie returns again, but for how long? And will that impact the overall quality of, or derail, this entry in the Halloween franchise? Hmmmm . . .

Watch Options

Where to watch Rob Zombie’s Halloween (2007)

Were we just complaining about retroactive continuity and the Halloween canon? Yeah, this remake by horror-head/rocker Rob Zombie is super retconned, not canon, and totally brutal. Zombie adds character depth to Michael and digs deeper into what’s up with the slasher and Laurie Strode (Scout Taylor-Compton in the Zombie Halloweens).

Watch Options

Where to watch Rob Zombie’s Halloween II (2009)

Zombie doubles down on the brutality and grue, and digs even deeper into what’s up with Michael and Laurie.

Watch Options

Even more horror franchise guides

  • How to Watch the Evil Dead Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Exorcist Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the A Nightmare on Elm Street Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Omen Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Scream Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Chucky Movies in Order

Where to watch Halloween (2018)

The first film in David Gordon Green’s now-complete new Halloween trilogy is a sequel to the original Night He Came Home from 1978, and sees Curtis return as Laurie Strode. But instead of occurring on the same night as with the original sequel, Halloween II, this 2018 film takes place 40 years later. (That’d make Michael, like, 61 years old—a Boomer. Shriiiiiiieeeek!)

Watch Options

Where to watch Halloween Kills (2021)

The second film in the David Gordon Green trilogy does, in fact, start where the previous film left off (as with the first two films in the series) and the mayhem continues.

Watch Options

Where to watch Halloween Ends (2022)

As the title suggests, this film caps off the trilogy and supposedly ends the saga. We say “supposedly” for two reasons: First, to avoid spoilers. The second reason? Miramax has acquired the series rights and there’s nothing stopping anyone from continuing to milk sweet, sweet blood from this moneymaker franchise. And that works for us, ‘cause even with all the continuity problems, one thing is true throughout the series: Every time you think Michael Myers is dead, he gets back up.

Watch Options

How to rent or buy the Halloween movies

We’ve researched and compiled rental and purchase pricing for the Halloween movies on Five video-on-demand (VOD) retailers: Amazon Prime Video, Apple TV+, Google Play Movies, Redbox, and VUDU.

Pricing for rentals is $2.99–$3.99, while purchase prices are $9.99–$17.99. In each price range below, the lower end is for standard definition (SD), while the higher end generally gets you higher resolution (HD or UHD).

To rent every Halloween movie, you’ll spend $46–$55. If you buy digital copies of every film, it’ll cost $146–$183.

How to watch the Halloween movies in order FAQs

Where can I watch Halloween series movies?

We've compiled this guide as a way to always show where to watch all the Halloween movies in order. It has automatically updating JustWatch.com links that will show you where to stream, rent, or buy all 13 Halloween movies. We've also included the information you need to watch the Halloween movies in chronological order.

More horror content from CableTV.com

  • Shudder Review
  • Screambox Review
  • Arrow Player Review

Why trust us? At age 9, Randy Harward begged his mom to take him to see An American Werewolf in London. She resisted but eventually relented.

Soon after that core cinematic experience, Randy discovered FANGORIA magazine and video stores. Several decades later, he supports himself and his raging horror habit by writing, reading, and talking about scary movies for CableTV.com.

The post He Came Home: How to Watch the Halloween Movies in Order appeared first on CableTV.com.

item.title: Ki, Ki, Ki, Watch, Watch, Watch: How to Watch the Friday the 13th Movies in Order
item.dc:creator: Randy Harward
item.description:
“Ki ki ki, ma ma ma . . . “ Jason Voorhees’ whispered, victim-stalking baby talk, hulking form, hockey mask, and emotionless brutality are why the Friday the 13th franchise is 45 years old, 12 movies deep, and as iconic as Ronald McDonald. Here’s how to watch the Friday the 13th movies in order.

The post Ki, Ki, Ki, Watch, Watch, Watch: How to Watch the Friday the 13th Movies in Order appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
How should I watch the Friday the 13th movies?

“Ki ki ki, ma ma ma … “ Jason Voorhees’ whispered—victim-stalking baby talk from the Friday the 13th movies is so ingrained in popular culture that even non-Friday fans recognize it. That creepy refrain—plus Jason’s hulking form, hockey mask, and emotionless brutality—is why the Friday the 13th franchise is 45 years old, 12 movies deep, and almost as iconic as Ronald McDonald. And it all explains why you wanna know how to watch the Friday the 13th movies in order.

Our guide tells you where to stream, rent, or buy all 12 Friday the 13th movies, one of the docs, and even the related-in-name-only Friday the 13th: The Series (well, we tried on that one). Now put on your hockey mask and go ki ki ki, watch watch watch.

Sponsored by DIRECTV

Binge-watch more of your favorite shows with DIRECTV

When the leaves fall, Fall TV shows drop—streaming with DIRECTV can make sure you catch them. New subscribers get three months of HBO Max™, Paramount+ with SHOWTIME, STARZ®, Cinemax®, and MGM+™ included with select packages (a $175 value).

You can watch a lot in three months, trust us, as professional TV watchers, the CableTV.com staff knows. Catch up on summer hits like The White Lotus and Dexter: Resurrection, and get into the new season of Peacemaker, or new shows like Outlander: Blood of My Blood and It: Welcome to Derry.

Sign up for a free trial today to see how DIRECTV is revolutionizing streaming TV with its Signature Packages, innovative Gemini streaming device, and curated Genre Packs. This is DIRECTV like you’ve never seen it.

Fast Wi-Fi saves lives

Keep your Friday the 13th marathon runnin’. Enter your zip code below to see faster internet service near you.

Jump to:

  • Watch the Friday the 13th movies in order
  • Rent or buy the Friday the 13th movies digitally
  • Watch the Friday the 13th TV series

Pro tip: Watching every Friday the 13th movie in order will take 11 hours and 41 minutes. (Bummer. We wish it’d come out to 13 hours. Maybe if a 13th film happens and it’s only 89 minutes long . . . )

Jack (Kevin Bacon) gets jacked up in Friday the 13th (1980). (Video screenshot from Paramount+)

What are the Friday the 13th movies?

Since the first Friday the 13th started choppin’ up campers (including Kevin Bacon) in 1980, there have been 11 sequels, an F13-in-name-only TV series, two meaty documentaries, and one iconic slasher: the hockey-masked, immortal Jason Voorhees.

After setting the first seven Friday the 13th movies at Camp Crystal Lake, the series sent Jason to Manhattan, Hell, outer space, and suburbia (with fellow slasher Freddy Krueger).

There are 12 total Friday the 13th films. Fans have begged for a 13th film that, for legal reasons, hasn’t materialized.

Li’l Jason (Ari Lehman) executes one of the all-time great jump-scares on Alice (Adrienne King) in Friday the 13th. (Video screenshot from Paramount+)

List of Friday the 13th movies in chronological and release order

  • Friday the 13th (1980)
  • Friday the 13th Part II (1981)
  • Friday the 13th Part III (1982)
  • Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter (1984)
  • Friday the 13th Part V: A New Beginning (1985)
  • Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives (1986)
  • Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood (1988)
  • Friday the 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan (1989)
  • Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday (1993)
  • Jason X (2002)
  • Freddy vs. Jason (2003)
  • Friday the 13th (2009)

How to watch the Friday the 13th movies in chronological order

What streaming service is Friday the 13th on? Use the automatically updating JustWatch links below to see where to stream, rent, or buy the Friday the 13th movies via on-demand streaming TV services or video-on-demand (VOD) retailers like Amazon Prime Video and Apple TV+.

Where to watch Friday the 13th (1980)

Ki, ki, ki . . . Ma, ma, ma . . . The bloody story of Camp Crystal Lake begins, and we learn the origins of Jason Voorhees—and that we’re “doomed!”

Watch Options

Where to watch Friday the 13th Part II (1981)

Jason’s all grown up now, and still doin’ his creepy chant—but he has a different look than you’d expect.

Watch Options

Where to watch Friday the 13th Part III (1982)

A 3D slasher movie holds so much promise and this one mostly delivers, with it’s-comin’-right-at-ya shots of yo-yos, joints, and eyeballs—plus some chef’s-kiss bad acting and WTF-ness. It’s also the sequel where Jason’s look finally comes together.

Watch Options

What is the best Friday the 13th movie?

Find out in Friday the 13th Movies Ranked.

Where to watch Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter (1984)

Corey Feldman elevates everything he touches—in his own way. In this chapter of the Friday the 13th series, Feldman’s portrayal of budding practical effects artist Tommy Boyle, the series’ best protagonist, made this the series’ best film.

Watch Options

Where to watch Friday the 13th Part V: A New Beginning (1985)

So, uh, how do you feel about major characters in a series getting replaced—with impostors? This could’ve been any slasher-in-the-woods movie, but they found a way to include Jason without actually (but also kinda) including him.

Watch Options

Where to watch Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives (1986)

Oh, thank goodness—he’s back. You know, the man behind the mask (as Alice Cooper sang). And he’s all covered in maggots and ready to get back to work hackin’ up campers.

Watch Options

More horror franchise guides

  • How to Watch the Texas Chainsaw Massacre Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Alien Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Terrifier Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Chucky Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Evil Dead Movies in Order

Where to watch Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood (1988)

You know what this series needs? A protagonist with superpowers. Like what? I dunno, how about telekinesis? That oughta lead to so many interesting encounters with Jason. It might involve some retroactive continuity, but whaddaya think?

Watch Options

Where to watch Friday the 13th Part VII: Jason Takes Manhattan (1989)

If you skip one movie in the Friday the 13th series, make it this one. It’s a boring but bloody hour-long booze cruise followed by a quick 30-minute stop in Manhattan. Kinda like a real cruise, but with mortal wounds instead of diarrhea.

Watch Options

Where to watch Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday (1993)

Can death stop an unstoppable killing machine? Not according to this entertaining (but not necessarily good) body-hopper plot!

Watch Options

Where to watch Jason X (2002)

Jason in space. Expect the good, the bad, and the deliciously goofy from Space Jason (Spa-son? Space-on? Ah, you get it).

Watch Options

Even more horror franchise guides

  • How to Watch the Exorcist Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the A Nightmare on Elm Street Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Scream Movies in Order
  • How to Watch the Halloween Movies in Order

Where to watch Freddy vs. Jason (2003)

It’s slasher vs. slasher, claws vs. machete, one-liners vs. stoic silence. Only one nightmare man can come out on top—place your bets and pray for daylight.

Watch Options

Where to watch Friday the 13th (2009)

Say what you will about remakes—sometimes they’re pretty good. Director Marcus Nispel is responsible for two such satisfying retreads: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (2003) and this one, where Jason’s bigger, badder, and more brutal-er.

Watch Options

Where to watch Crystal Lake Memories: The Complete History of Friday the 13th (2013)

Can’t get enough Friday the 13th? Do you have to know everything about the series? Here’s how you can watch two fan-favorite documentaries about the films.

At nearly 7 hours long, Crystal Lake Memories: The Complete History of Friday the 13th (2013) is comprehensive (to say the least). We recommend watching this one first.

His Name Was Jason: 30 Years of Friday the 13th (2010) is also worth watching—and it’s only 90 minutes long.

Watch Options

How to rent or buy the Friday the 13th movies

If the Friday the 13th movies aren’t on Paramount+ with SHOWTIME or one of your other streaming services, don’t despair. You can still rent or buy the films from the video-on-demand (VOD) retailers in the JustWatch links above.

Pro tip: If you don’t need perfect 4K HDR video, but you have a 4K TV with AI-upscaling, rent or buy the Friday the 13th films in HD (digital) or on Blu-ray (disc). Your TV will make the movies look almost as good as 4K. Also, you’ll save a few bucks.

How to watch Friday the 13th: The Series (1987–1990)

Fans wanting an episodic dose of Jason should know he’s not in Friday the 13th: The Series. The show has nothing to do with Friday the 13th movies—it’s about a store full of cursed objects. You can skip it, but it’s a decent watch if you’re into ‘80s horror anthology shows like Tales from the Darkside or Freddy’s Nightmares.

Friday the 13th: The Series isn’t on a streaming service—but it is on YouTube. And, if you love it, you can buy the series on DVD.

Watch Options

How to watch the Friday the 13th movies in order FAQ

What is the chronological order of Friday the 13th?

The Friday the 13th series has no prequels, so you can watch the Friday the 13th movies in chronological order by following release order:

  • Friday the 13th (1980)
  • Friday the 13th Part II (1981)
  • Friday the 13th Part III (1982)
  • Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter (1984)
  • Friday the 13th Part V: A New Beginning (1985)
  • Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives (1986)
  • Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood (1988)
  • Friday the 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan (1989)
  • Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday (1993)
  • Jason X (2002)
  • Freddy vs. Jason (2003)
  • Friday the 13th (2009)

What streaming service is Friday the 13th on?

You've come to the right place. Our handy reference guide has automatically updating JustWatch links that should always have the information you seek—for all 12 Friday the 13th films. That link up there will take you to the info for Friday the 13th (1980). Scroll down to see the same info for the rest of the series.

Let’s start watching!

  • Paramount+ with SHOWTIME Review
  • Best Streaming Services for Horror Fans
  • Shudder Review

Why you can trust our how-to-watch horror franchise guides

At age 9, Randy Harward begged his mom to take him to see An American Werewolf in London. She resisted but eventually relented. Soon after that core cinematic experience, Randy discovered FANGORIA magazine and video stores. Several decades later, he supports himself and his raging horror habit by writing, reading, and talking about scary movies for CableTV.com.

The post Ki, Ki, Ki, Watch, Watch, Watch: How to Watch the Friday the 13th Movies in Order appeared first on CableTV.com.

Is DISH or DIRECTV better?

DISH Network is our Best of the Best award winner for the best satellite TV provider and the best TV provider for kids—the latter for five years running—and the DISH Hopper 3 DVR is the best receiver/DVR around.

DIRECTV is the best satellite TV provider for sports since it has more sports channels and awesome sports add-on packages. And DIRECTV now offers a two-year price guarantee—but also a monthly fee for its Genie DVR (formerly included with your plan).

So which is the best satellite TV provider, DISH or DIRECTV? We’re going with DISH—again—because DISH TV service is more affordable and transparent.

Why you should trust us: Our editorial team collectively spends thousands of hours comparing, testing and researching every major service provider to keep our guides and reviews up-to-date.

We also work closely with our compliance specialists to verify brand pricing, deals, and terms, to make sure we’re bringing you the most accurate information we can.

Sponsored by DIRECTV

Binge-watch more of your favorite shows with DIRECTV

When the leaves fall, Fall TV shows drop—streaming with DIRECTV can make sure you catch them. New subscribers get three months of HBO Max™, Paramount+ with SHOWTIME, STARZ®, Cinemax®, and MGM+™ included with select packages (a $175 value).

You can watch a lot in three months, trust us, as professional TV watchers, the CableTV.com staff knows. Catch up on summer hits like The White Lotus and Dexter: Resurrection, and get into the new season of Peacemaker, or new shows like Outlander: Blood of My Blood and It: Welcome to Derry.

Sign up for a free trial today to see how DIRECTV is revolutionizing streaming TV with its Signature Packages, innovative Gemini streaming device, and curated Genre Packs. This is DIRECTV like you’ve never seen it.

DISH and DIRECTV bundles

DISH and DIRECTV don’t sell internet service, but you can pair these TV providers with internet service providers near you.

Enter your zip code below to find out the best ISPs near you.

View Plans for DISH

View Plans for DIRECTV

DISH vs. DIRECTV deals and promotions

Before you choose a DISH or DIRECTV plan, have a look at the promotions each provider offers.

DISH deals and promotions

  • Free Paramount+ with SHOWTIME®, STARZ®, and the DISH Movie Pack: For three months when you sign up.
  • DISH 55 (for seniors) and Those Who Serve (active military, first responders, nurses, teachers, and veterans) include various perks like extra channels, free movie rentals, six free months of equipment protection, and upgraded identity theft protection.

DIRECTV deals and promotions

  • Free premium channels: When you order the ENTERTAINMENT All Included package or above, you can get CINEMAX®, MGM+™, HBO Max, Paramount+ with SHOWTIME, and STARZ® free for three months.

And don’t forget to check out our dedicated DISH deals and DIRECTV deals pages.

Compare DISH vs. DIRECTV head to head

Read DIRECTV Review

Data effective as of post date. Offers may vary by location and are subject to change. See full disclaimer regarding pricing and features for more information.

DISH’s strong points are its two-year price guarantee, industry-leading Hopper 3 DVR, kids programming, and parental controls.

DIRECTV has the best sports channels and add-on packages, and the provider now has a two-year price guarantee. That said, DIRECTV plans are expensive and no longer include the Genie DVR—you’ll pay a $15 monthly Advanced Receiver Service Fee for it now.

Wanna know more before you sign up? We’ve dug into packages, features, and more, so you can find the right DISH or DIRECTV plan for you.

DISH vs. DIRECTV packages and pricing

With nine packages to choose from, things can get a little, um . . . confusing. But have no fear! We’ve made it easy to pick a plan by researching every DISH and DIRECTV package and listing up-to-date pricing, channel counts, and popular channels.

DISH packages and pricing

America’s Top 120 $96.99/mo.** 190 Disney Channel, ESPN, and more View Plan

America’s Top 200
Best package 		$116.99/mo.** 240+ Disney Junior, Hallmark Channel, and more View Plan

Data effective as of post date. Not all offers available in all areas. See full disclaimer regarding pricing and features for more information.

Some DISH and DIRECTV packages have higher-than-average monthly payments, but price protection is a rare find in an industry that thrives on raising prices after promotional periods. The peace of mind might be worth the extra money.

We recommend the DISH Americas Top 200 package for true-blue TV fans because it includes more than 240 channels, like Disney HD and Investigation Discovery, for the price of $116.99/mo..

DISH includes the Hopper Duo DVR with its plans, but it charges a $5.00 service fee and a $10.00 upgrade fee if you want the far superior Hopper 3 DVR instead.

For more insights into DISH TV service, read our full DISH review—highlighting plans, channel lineups, and more.

View DISH Plans

Pro tip: Price protection is a rare find in an industry that thrives on raising prices after promotional periods. DISH and DIRECTV both have two-year contracts with two-year price guarantees.

DIRECTV packages and pricing

Package Price† Channel count Popular channels Details
ENTERTAINMENT All Included $89.99/mo. for 24 mos. plus taxes and fees 165+ ESPN, TNT, and more View plans
CHOICE™ All Included $94.99/mo. for 24 mos. plus taxes and fees 200+ FX, IFC, and more View plans
ULTIMATE All Included $124.99/mo. for 24 mos. plus taxes and fees 270+ Boomerang, FLIX, and more View plans
PREMIER™ All Included
Best package 		$169.99/mo. for 24 mos. plus taxes and fees 340+ HBO, CINEMAX, and more View plans

Data effective as of post date. Not all offers available in all areas. See full disclaimer regarding pricing and features for more information.

DIRECTV’s new price guarantee is so much more transparent than the provider’s old way of doing things (affordable payment in the first year, steep price hike in the second).

We used to recommend DIRECTV’s CHOICE All Included package because it was the most affordable way to get free NFL SUNDAY TICKET and premium channels at signup.

Now that YouTube TV has NFL SUNDAY TICKET and DIRECTV has a price guarantee, it’s less risky to choose the provider’s top package, PREMIER All Included. For $169.99/mo., PREMIER All Included has every channel DIRECTV carries—including premium channels.

All DIRECTV packages require the Genie DVR, so the associated Advanced Receiver Service Fee adds $15 to your monthly payment.

Read our comprehensive DIRECTV review to learn more about plans, channel lineups, and features.

View DIRECTV Plans

DISH vs. DIRECTV channels

DIRECTV has 165–340+ channels, including more sports channels than any other provider, along with regional sports networks. That’s why it’s our best TV provider for sports. But that doesn’t mean DIRECTV doesn’t have a slew of popular cable channels in every category: entertainment, news, kids & family, premium channels, and more.

Check out our comprehensive DIRECTV channel lineup guide to see which packages have the channels you want. You’ll also be able to find channel numbers for each network except for your local broadcast affiliates (channel numbers for those vary by location).

DISH has 190–290+ channels, with more and better kids’ channels than DIRECTV, which is why DISH gets our Best of the Best award as the best TV provider for families and kids. And, while DISH doesn’t have as many sports channels as DIRECTV, it has a major one that DIRECTV lacks: beIN Sports.

See exactly which sports, entertainment, family, and premium channels DISH carries in our DISH channel lineup guide.

DISH vs. DIRECTV sports

DISH DIRECTV
Sports channels (not incl. RSNs) 78 (59 in HD) 52 (42 in HD)
Regional sports networks (RSNs)* 25 16
Sports add-ons 10 9
Pay-per-view live sports ✔ ✔
Sports-friendly DVR features
  • Picture-in-picture

  • GameFinder

  • Quad split-screen
    		•

    Sports apps

  • DraftKings
    		•
  • DIRECTV app

  • DIRECTV Sports Bar Finder
    		•

    Data effective as of post date.
    *Not all Regional Sports Networks (RSNs) are available everywhere.

    As we’ve mentioned, we think DIRECTV is the best TV provider for sports—our DIRECTV Sports Packages page is a great place to see everything the satellite service offers for sports fans. But DISH is no slouch in the sportsball department either. Just look at that table above.

    DISH beats DIRECTV in almost every sports category. But there are some details not captured in those numbers. Let’s break down some key differences between the satellite TV rivals’ sports content.

    • DISH’s channel count includes 12 beIN SPORTS CONNECT and 5 TUDNxtra channels, which isn’t the same as 17 different sports networks. But even without counting those overflow channels, DISH still has 61 sports channels to DIRECTV’s 52.
    • DISH doesn’t have Fox College Sports, GolTV, Next Level Sports, TyC Sports, and Univision Deportes.
    • DIRECTV doesn’t have beIN Sports, Lo Mejor de Liga MX, Outside TV, Stadium, WILLOW, World Fishing Network, and Zona Fútbol. It’s also missing NFL RedZone.
    • Not all regional sports networks (RSNs) are available everywhere. The ones you get will depend on your zip code, but DIRECTV has a larger selection of RSNs compared to DISH.
    • DIRECTV and DISH have the seasonal sports add-ons FOX Soccer Plus, MLB Extra Innings, NBA League Pass, and NHL Center Ice.

    We’ve also compiled a sports channels-only comparison table so you can see exactly which ones DISH and DIRECTV have. Fair warning: This is a long table.

    DISH vs. DIRECTV sports channels

    To us, the DISH vs. DIRECTV sportsball battle comes down to available add-ons. RSNs are crucial for MLB, NBA, and NHL fans, so DIRECTV having the most RSNs is huge for watching in-market games.

    Without the add-ons, each provider has a balanced lineup of sports channels—but DISH has more of them, not to mention more variety. So we wouldn’t dismiss DISH just because DIRECTV has those juicy add-ons and RSNs. It all depends on what sports you enjoy watching.

    Pro tip: Visit our CableTV.com Sports hub page for a closer look at league-specific guides and other resources to help you watch your favorite sports.

    DISH vs. DIRECTV equipment and features

    Although DISH and DIRECTV have similar channel counts and first-year pricing, the two satellite TV providers differ quite a bit in terms of equipment and features.

    Read on to find out about everything from DVRs to bundling your TV service with internet.

    DVRs

    TBH, a DVR can make or break your TV experience. Luckily, you can’t lose with the DISH Hopper 3 and DIRECTV Genie.

    DISH Hopper 3 vs. DIRECTV Genie

    DVR Price Storage Simultaneous
    recordings     		Video
    quality     		Details
    DISH Hopper 3
    Best DVR     		$10.00/mo. 2,000 hrs. 16 Up to 4K Ultra HD Read Hopper review
    DIRECTV Genie $15.00/mo. 200 hrs. 5 Up to 4K Ultra HD Read Genie review
    DIRECTV Genie 2 $15.00/mo. (plus $99 bridge fee due at signup) 450 hrs. 7 Up to 4K Ultra HD Read Genie review

    DISH Hopper 3

    While DISH has more than one DVR, we recommend the Hopper 3 if you want an amazing DVR experience. (While the Hopper Duo comes included with most DISH packages, it’s basic af.)

    The Hopper 3 is the best DVR out there, with 2,000 hours of storage capacity, 16 simultaneous recordings, and more built-in streaming apps than the DIRECTV Genie. If DVRs are your thing, go with DISH.

    DIRECTV Genie

    The Genie DVR ain’t too shabby, either. The standard Genie stores 200 HD hours with five simultaneous recordings. The wireless Genie 2 has 450 hours of HD storage and seven simultaneous recordings. Both require the $15-a-month Advanced Receiver Service Fee, and the Genie 2 has a $99 bridge fee (for Wi-Fi setup) due when you sign up.

    To learn more, read our Genie review.

    Pro tip: You can learn more about how the Hopper 3 and the Genie compare head to head by reading our in-depth vs. article.

    Installation

    When you sign up for DISH, your service includes the cost of standard installation from a professional.

    To make installation even smoother, you can view your technician’s photo, monitor their location, and review your scheduled time with the appointment feature in the MyDISH app. In this user-friendly world, it’s a feature we appreciate and think more TV providers should implement.

    While DIRECTV charges a $20 activation fee to start your service, it doesn’t technically charge anything for installation. Still, 20 bucks is 20 bucks, amirite?

    Watch out: DIRECTV has other hidden fees, too. Check out our Hidden Costs of DIRECTV guide for more details before you sign up.

    It would be nice if DIRECTV got a technician-tracker tool like DISH. There are a few complaints online that make us concerned about technicians arriving late or rescheduling last minute.

    In the end, we think DISH is the clear winner when it comes to installation.

    Streaming apps

    The DISH Anywhere app and DIRECTV app are on-the-go streaming apps that turn your phone or tablet into a tiny mobile TV.

    DISH Anywhere app

    The DISH Anywhere mobile app (Android, iOS) lets you watch your live TV channels and on-demand movies and shows while you’re away from home.

    You can even transfer your DVR recordings from your DISH Hopper 3 to your mobile device so you can watch them offline wherever you are. What’s more, DISH Anywhere allows you to set and manage DVR timers while you’re away. And parents will love the ability to adjust DISH’s top-notch parental controls, with separate profiles for each child—we love this.

    To learn more about this value-adding DISH perk, check out our DISH Anywhere app guide.

    DIRECTV app

    The DIRECTV app (Android, iOS) has features similar to those of the DISH Anywhere app. You can stream live channels and on-demand content from your DIRECTV package and watch/set/manage DVR recordings. And the app even acts as a voice remote so you can avoid sticking your hand between the couch cushions (eeeeewwwww) if you misplace your Genie clicker again.

    And just like with DISH Anywhere, you can set and manage parental controls from the DIRECTV App. But DIRECTV’s parental controls aren’t quite as good as DISH’s, which the company created in a partnership with Common Sense Media.

    So we say the DISH Anywhere is superior, with a more intuitive user experience. Plus, as we keep pointing out, DISH is a better satellite TV provider than DIRECTV.

    DISH vs. DIRECTV FAQ

    What's the difference between DISH and DIRECTV?

    Satellite TV providers DISH and DIRECTV both have two-year contracts with price guarantees, plus fairly similar plans and pricing. But there are some key differences between the TV services:

    • DISH has 190–290+, while DIRECTV has 165–340+
    • DIRECTV has more sports channels.
    • DIRECTV charges a $15 Advanced Receiver Service Fee for the Genie DVRs.
    • DISH charges $10 a month for its Hopper 3 DVR.
    • The DISH Hopper 3 stores 2,000 hours and lets you record 16 programs at once. DIRECTV's Genie stores 200 hours and has five simultaneous recordings, and the Genie 2 stores 450 hours and has seven simultaneous recordings.

    Is DIRECTV's picture better than DISH?

    There's not a big difference in picture quality between DISH and DIRECTV. Live and on-demand content from both providers is in 1080p high definition (HD), and the DISH Hopper 3 and DIRECTV Genie both support 4K content.

    Where is satellite TV available?

    Satellite TV is available across the US—basically, anywhere you can set up a south-facing satellite dish. This might be an issue for some apartment buildings without a clear shot of the southern sky.

    Is satellite TV reliable?

    Yes, satellite TV technology has come a long way and can provide a reliable signal through most weather conditions.

    What is the cheapest satellite TV package?

    DIRECTV ENTERTAINMENT All Included ($89.99/mo., 165+ channels, two-year price lock) is the cheapest satellite TV package. DISH America's Top 120 ($96.99/mo., 190 channels) is a comparable option and it has a two-year price guarantee.

    What is the best satellite TV deal?

    DISH America’s Top 250 ($126.99/mo., 290+ channels) has the best cost per channel between all DISH and DIRECTV plans. Of course, if you aren’t going to watch all those channels, or if it’s missing any of your favorites, it might not be the best deal for you.

    Are there low-income options for satellite TV?

    While participants in the U.S. Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) can get assistance with internet bills, TV isn’t considered a utility and doesn’t come with the same benefit. But over-the-air and streaming TV can be affordable alternatives. Check out our Free and Low-Cost Cable TV guide for more information.

    Which is the worst satellite TV package?

    Speaking purely to cost per channel, DIRECTV's PREMIER All Included ($169.99/mo.) is the worst value. However, since that cost includes all the most popular premium channels (HBO Max, STARZ, Paramount+ with SHOWTIME®, CINEMAX, and MGM+) it’s a pretty awesome “worst package.”

    How does satellite TV work?

    Satellite TV involves a TV provider sending a signal into space, where it bounces off of a satellite and back down to the dish on your roof, which routes the signal to your receiver.

    Are there other satellite TV options besides DIRECTV and DISH?

    There really isn’t an alternative to DIRECTV or DISH, which are the only satellite TV providers in the US. But if you’re open to other types of TV service, you can check out cable TV providers or streaming TV services.

    Why you should trust us

    Our experts have logged hundreds of hours of hands-on testing and research on both DIRECTV and DISH Network. For this piece, we compare DISH and DIRECTV, rating the satellite TV providers on bang for your buck, reliability, features, and customer satisfaction so our readers can make informed buying decisions.

    For more information on our process, check out our How We Rank page.

    Related articles

    • DISH Review
    • DIRECTV Review
    • Best TV Providers
    • Best Satellite TV Providers

    * Packages for existing customers only

    **All offers require 2-year commitment with early termination fee and eAutoPay.

PREMIER™: ($199.98/mo. w/req’d $10/mo. TV Access Fee & Regional Sports Fee of up to $19.99/mo.) w/ 24-mo. agmt. Autopay and paperless bill req’d. One-time $49.95 activation fee is extra and applies.

    The post DISH vs. DIRECTV: Cost, Plans, and More appeared first on CableTV.com.

item.title: Eeeeewwww! The 13 Nastiest Movies on Tubi That You Can Stream For Free
item.dc:creator: Randy Harward
item.description:
Hey, gorehounds: Tubi has some gnarly, nasty horror movies—ones that redefine “hard to watch”—and you can stream them for free. Here are 13 of the nastiest sick flicks on Tubi. Watching them is entirely your decision, so don’t send us your therapy bills if you do.

The post Eeeeewwww! The 13 Nastiest Movies on Tubi That You Can Stream For Free appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
What are the nastiest movies on Tubi?

Hey, gorehounds: You’ll find some of the gnarliest, nastiest movies on Tubi—where you can stream them for free. But there’s an extra layer of weirdness to watching the nastiest movies on Tubi since it’s a free, ad-supported (FAST) streaming service. In this article, we highlight 13 examples of the cinematic gnarliness found on Tubi, along with the interesting ads paired with the films.

PSA: Watching these movies is entirely your decision, so don’t send us your therapy bills if you do.

PSA 2. SPOILERS ahead (tee-hee!)

Sponsored by DIRECTV

Binge-watch more of your favorite shows with DIRECTV

When the leaves fall, Fall TV shows drop—streaming with DIRECTV can make sure you catch them. New subscribers get three months of HBO Max™, Paramount+ with SHOWTIME, STARZ®, Cinemax®, and MGM+™ included with select packages (a $175 value).

You can watch a lot in three months, trust us, as professional TV watchers, the CableTV.com staff knows. Catch up on summer hits like The White Lotus and Dexter: Resurrection, and get into the new season of Peacemaker, or new shows like Outlander: Blood of My Blood and It: Welcome to Derry.

Sign up for a free trial today to see how DIRECTV is revolutionizing streaming TV with its Signature Packages, innovative Gemini streaming device, and curated Genre Packs. This is DIRECTV like you’ve never seen it.

Is there inappropriate content on Tubi?

Yes, the entire Tubi library is uncensored, and many movies have extreme violence or sexual content (but not porn). Parents should be extra vigilant, since it’s easy for kids to sign up for a free account—with an honor-system age check—then, they can access every axe murder and sex scene on the service. Fortunately, Tubi has parental controls in the Settings menu.

Uncensored movies on a free streaming service?! The horror. (Video screenshot from Martyrs via Tubi)

The 13 Nastiest Movies on Tubi

Here they are, folks. Thirteen of the nastiest movies on Tubi. We’ve got diabolical killer clowns, spontaneous at-home C-sections, pervy slashers that sound like Donald Duck, ancient demons on a rampage, scorned women getting revenge, borderline incoherence and incompetence, and even a poop monster.

List of the nastiest movies on Tubi (not ranked)

  • Thanatomorphose (2012)
  • Septic Man (2013)
  • Terrifier 2 (2022)
  • Premutos: The Fallen Angel (1997)
  • American Guinea Pig: Sacrifice (2017)
  • Inside (2007)
  • The Necro Files (1997)
  • Terrifier (2016)
  • Martyrs (2008)
  • Beyond the Darkness (1979)
  • I Spit on Your Grave (1978)
  • The New York Ripper (1982)
  • No Reason (2010)

1. Thanatomorphose (2012)

Plot: After a rough night of sex, a nurse’s body begins to decay as though she’s dead. As she falls apart, she tries to keep herself together—but resorts to storing herself in jars.

Nastiness: Decayed animal corpse. So many maggots. Poop. Copious vomit. Face vs. hammer. A living person in an increasingly advanced state of gooey, sloughing decomposition—but who’s still horny (!).

Interesting ads:

  • LifeLock by Norton—Are you spontaneously decaying and living through it? Secure your identity now before someone, uh, steals it.
  • McDonald’s—Because of course you’re hungry (and on a budget).
  • Talenti Gelato and Sorbetto—Because of course you’ll want dessert.
  • A Place for Mom—Senior living advice? I think we’re past that.
  • Walden University—A teaching degree? Also a tad too late.

Rotting alive is hard work. Rest often. (Video screenshot from Tubi)

Watch or not: Thanatomorphose makes a solid point about sexual trauma, but the story won’t suck you in. It will, however, make you blow chunks.

Slow internet is nasty

You’ll need fast internet to see every nasty detail in these nasty movies. Enter your zip code to see internet providers near you.

2. Septic Man (2013)

Plot: A community’s water supply has become polluted with a litany of bacteria: cryptosporidium, e. coli, etc. A creepy corporate stooge offers a plumber $200,000 to solve the crisis. The tradesman gets trapped in a sewer and begins to transform.

Nastiness: Poop. Lots of poop. Poop monster. Puke (natch). Apropos of nothing, a cold open shows a woman having a painful blowout in the nastiest bathroom. Dead baby in a sewer. Juice squeezed from sewer rats for nutrition. Chainsaw hemicorporectomy. The birth of a poop monster/human baby. A man with multiple open, festering wounds wading in an entire community’s filth—and more—for most of the film.

Interesting ads:

  • Express Scripts Pharmacy—If you watch Septic Man, you will want antibiotics.
  • FreeSolarDinner.com—How about a nice beefy dinner at Ruth’s Chris steakhouse (after a brief presentation)?
  • A Place for Mom—Because elderly people poop?
  • Little Caesar’s—’Cause it tastes like (four-letter word, rhymes with “poop”).
  • AARP—Because elderly people . . .

Somebody’s life is about to change—we hope this dude washed his hands first. (Video screenshot from Tubi)

Watch or not: Nope—but not necessarily because of the poop (it’s fun to say “poop”). Septic Man is disgusting and dull. We mostly just watch a guy stew in sewer water among bobbing bodies and body parts (a serial killer’s handiwork, in an odd subplot) as he slowly morphs into a slimy, bumpy, bloody poop monster. He notches only one kill in the whole film; the premise demands a rampage. Also, there’s poop. So much poop.

3. Terrifier 2 (2022)

Plot: Art the Clown (David Howard Thornton) returns with his sick bag of tricks for a sadistic 2.5-hour sick-a-thon that picks up where the first one left off and runs amok. And this time, Art has an imaginary daughter/accomplice, The Little Pale Girl (Amelie McClain).

Nastiness: Tommy gun massacre, eyeball removal-slash-accessorization, cereal box razor blades, beheadings, scalpings, bone-breaking, flaying, wound-salting, human-head candy dish, acid splashing, bludgeoning, possum mutilation, and a maggot-infested still-beating heart in a gift box.

Interesting ads:

  • Experian—Scared of killer clowns? What about identity theft?!
  • Airheads—Well, there was a cotton candy flavor . . .
  • State Farm—Got killer clown coverage?
  • Instacart—because Terrifier 2 really DELIVERS THE GROSS-ERIES! Heeeeeeee-HAAAAWWWWW!

Watch or not:
If you’re a gore fan, you kinda totally have to see Damien Leone’s Terrifier 2—especially if you like ‘80s slasher movies. But first, ask yourself exactly how much you enjoy blood ‘n’ guts ‘cause these kills are wild.

In Art the Clown’s world, this is what passes for a meet-cute scene. (Video screenshot)

4. American Guinea Pig: Sacrifice (2017)

Plot: A disturbed man hopes to summon a demon through self-mutilation—using unintentionally comical torture implements.

Nastiness: Breathless (all-voiceover) overacting, pretentious writing, and ridiculous torture tools contribute as much to Sacrifice’s cringe-worthiness as the gore scenes. We see oral stimulation performed on a butter-knife wound, a Phillips-head bit supposedly penetrating skull, toenail removal, tongue-chewing, gut-kneading, and two prolonged scenes showing the graphic mutilation of what we’ll call a “hog.”

Interesting ads:

    • BetterHelp online therapy—The Tubi ad server is worried about you.
    • Blue Bunny Ice Cream—To feel better after giving yourself boo-boos?

Watch or not:
Nobody really watches these films for the story—but Poison Rouge’s Sacrifice is so far up its own kiester that an hour feels like a lifetime. Skip it.

Stand back, or I’m gonna use this! (Video screenshot)

5. Premutos: The Fallen Angel (1997)

Plot: In another barely coherent (even with subtitles) extreme horror-comedy from German goremeister Olaf Ittenbach, a demon more senior to Lucifer awakens—along with a zombie army—and chaotic carnage ensues.

Nastiness: Heads fly, roll, splat, split, and ‘splode throughout the film. Aside from that, we see three extra-gross monster transformations, vertical and horizontal torso splitting, face-chewing, more hog abuse, and a splatter-ific 30-minute chainsaw finale.

Interesting ads:

  • FOX’s Housebroken—Animated TV-14 palate cleanser, anyone?
  • Paula’s Choice Skin System—Did we mistake the monsters and victims for people with blemishes?
  • CashNetUSA.com—You seem like a dirtbag. You want a payday loan?

Watch or not:
Olaf Ittenbach makes gore-no flicks—all gore, no story—and Premutos: The Fallen Angel seems like an imitation of Peter Jackson’s incredibly funny and freaky Braindead (a/k/a Dead Alive). Watch that if you want to see a good movie. Otherwise, Premutos is worth a casual watch as one of the goriest movies on Tubi.

Zombies break down the door, then the fourth wall. (Video screenshot)

6. Inside (2007)

Plot: A depressed, recently widowed expectant mother must defend herself against a devious intruder who wants the baby for herself.

Nastiness: The accidental brutal killing of a loved one, male pelvic-perineal mutilation by scissors, ocular impalement, scissors-to-the-forehead, shotgun-to-the-head (close-up), facial charring by hairspray flamethrower, and a non-emergent home C-section—also by scissors.

Interesting ads:

  • Frank’s Red Hot—If there’s one thing Inside doesn’t need, it’s extra sauce.
  • Allstate—For your next tragic accident.
  • Gain, Tide, and Downy Fabric Softener—Keep those onesies smelling fresh and feeling soft.

Watch or not:
Alexandre Bustillo and Julien Maury’s masterpiece of New French Extremity is one of the most disturbing movies on Tubi. It’s also a taut thriller, and the visceral graphic violence fits the story. Watch it.

Our pregnant protagonist insults a creepy nurse. (Video screenshot)

You’re doin’ it wrong

Hello, teen. Did you come here looking for a guide for finding the smut (that eludes you in real life) on Tubi? (Protest all you want; Google Analytics told us everything.) Well, if you wound up here, you’re doin’ it wrong.

This has been a Public Service Announcement from CableTV.com. We won’t tell your mom (probably). And now back to our disgusting movie recommendations.

7. The Necro Files (1997)

Plot: Thanks to a Satanic cult, an undead (and ridiculously endowed) serial killer rampages through town, chased by two doofus detectives and a flying demon baby.

Nastiness: Post-mortem C-section (the “C” stands for cannibalism), infant (read: obvious doll) sacrifice, a manual Bobbitting, zombie gut-play using real animal innards, a zombie-on-inflatable doll love scene, and sexual assault with aforementioned knob-a-saurus.

Interesting ads:

  • Charmin Ultra Soft—Because this movie is utter (but entertaining) crap.
  • Arby’s—They have the meats.
  • Asana—Content management systems . . . for organized rampages?

Watch or not:
A classic of ‘90s shot-on-video horror, Matt Jaissle’s The Necro Files is a feast for gorehounds with an appetite for so-bad-it’s-goodness.

When there is no more room in Hell, the dead baby dolls will rise. (Video screenshot)

8. Terrifier (2016)

Plot: A mute killer clown uses creativity and cruelty to terrorize a town.

Nastiness: A human-head jack-o’-lantern, a blown-up bathroom, graphic mutilation, multiple gunshots to a single face, and a vertical hemicorporectomy performed with a rusty hacksaw on an upside-down woman.

Interesting ads:

  • Missing trailer—Sure, Terrifier fans will love your PG-13 thriller.
  • Squarespace—Because Art the Clown needs an online store?
  • Proactiv—Does clown makeup cause skin irritation?

Watch or not:
Damien Leone’s first feature-length Art the Clown movie is sadistic and scary—and for advanced horror fans only.

Add withering, judgmental stinkeye to Art the Clown’s scary bag o’ tricks. (Video screenshot)

Pro tip: If you like the 13 Nastiest Movies on Tubi, you’ll probably love Best Cannibal Movies—with Meal Pairing Suggestions.

9. Martyrs (2008)

Plot: A young French woman and her friend plot revenge on the cultists who imprisoned and tortured one of them.

Nastiness: Child abuse, a skinned body, removal of a bolted-on mask, a legitimately nightmarish “creature,” and shotgun vs. family.

Interesting ads:

  • 5-Hour Energy—You won’t need it to stay awake for Martyrs.
  • White Claw Hard Seltzer—You can use it to numb the pain.
  • French’s Mustard—French film, “French” condiment.

Watch or not:
Watch. Pascal Laugier’s Martyrs is emotionally draining but gripping from start to finish. It’s worth the trauma.

How disturbing is Martyrs? It’s written all over Lucie’s face in this very early scene. (Video screenshot)

10. Beyond the Darkness (1979)

Plot: A grieving taxidermist exhumes his girlfriend’s body and, with help from his horny housekeeper, stuffs and preserves the corpse—while committing more murders to cover up the crime.

Nastiness: Graphic disembowelment, heart-eating, fingernail pulling, eyeball gouging, graphic body disposal, and a housekeeper eating beef stew with her mouth open.

Interesting ads:

  • Glade Plug-Ins—What’s that smell coming from the basement?
  • Expedia—GTFO on the cheap.
  • Instagram Tools—Parental controls (LMAO).

Watch or not:
Watch. There’s just enough story to make Joe D’Amato’s Beyond the Darkness worth watching—but keep a barf bucket ready.

Your name wouldn’t happen to be . . . Ralph? (Video screenshot)

Pro tip: Do you love free streaming TV services? Check out Freebie the Love Bundle in our 9 Streaming Bundles to Replace Cable guide. You’ll be shocked at how much TV you can get for nothing.

11. I Spit on Your Grave (1978)

Plot: Meir Zarchi’s rape revenge flick follows a writer (Camille Keaton) who rents a country home to work on a book, only to become prey for hillbilly rapists and a mentally challenged grocery delivery boy.

Nastiness: Watching 30 straight minutes of vicious, repeated, dehumanizing sexual assault is beyond difficult. The other half is sweet, sweet revenge: mid-coital hanging, outboard motor evisceration, hatchet burial, and pre-coital castration.

Interesting ads:

  • Instacart—We see you’re interested in grocery delivery . . .
  • Myfembree—Menstrual medication?!
  • Applebee’s—Also makes you sick.

Watch or not:
Up to you. The revenge is sweet (hence, the film’s original title: Day of the Woman)—but to see it, you’ll have to endure the brutal, heartbreaking, and prolonged sexual assault scenes.

Sweet revenge, comin’ in hot! (Video screenshot)

12. The New York Ripper (1982)

Plot: In Lucio Fulci’s notorious giallo, a serial killer who talks like Donald Duck brutally murders women in NYC while taunting the police on the phone.

Nastiness: Broken-bottle evisceration, sliced eyeballs, sexual violence, graphic and prolonged stabbings.

Interesting ads:

  • Whooping cough vaccination PSA—So you don’t sound like a murderous Donald Duck?
  • Entresto—Heart medication (well, you might need it).
  • Kay Jewelers—Awwwww, every kiss begins with Kay!

Watch or not:
Nothing says “must see” like a quacking killer. But it’s hard to laugh at one of the meanest Giallo movies ever—until the ridiculous ending.

I’m sorry, did I wake you? I just called to say . . . QUACK! (Video screenshot)

13. No Reason (2010)

Plot: A woman searching for redemption goes through Hell—which resembles a butcher shop in a bondage club—to find it.

Nastiness: Buckets of blood, heaps of ragged flesh, piles of detailed severed heads and limbs, disembowelment, sexual violence, pornographic scenes, and the “plot.”

Interesting ads:

  • CSL Plasma donation centers—‘Nuff said?
  • Eckrich Smoked Sausages—Who’s hungry? Not us.

Watch or not:
Olaf Ittenbach’s No Reason is confusing and pretentious, but the copious, shocking gore effects—the priority in German underground horror—will make your chunks blow chunks. Gore geeks only.

And you thought your teachers were weird. (Video screenshot)

Get more gore

  • Best Streaming Services for Horror Fans
  • Tubi Review
  • Shudder Review
  • Screambox Review

The Nastiest Movies on Tubi FAQ

Is Tubi content censored?

Tubi doesn't censor movies and shows, but it has some extremely violent and sexual content (no hardcore pornography, though). Don't leave your child unattended or you might catch them watching the nastiest movies on Tubi.

Why trust us? At age 9, Randy Harward begged his mom to take him to see An American Werewolf in London. She resisted but eventually relented.

Soon after that core cinematic experience, Randy discovered FANGORIA magazine and video stores. Several decades later, he supports himself and his raging horror habit by writing, reading, and talking about scary movies for CableTV.com.
